nodes.text: An IoT based system using Node MCU can implement integrated smart security, smart home automation, and environment monitoring that overcomes range and reliability drawbacks of existing short range wireless methods

Existing home automation methods have limitations: Bluetooth has limited range (~10 m), voice systems suffer from low signal to noise ratio dependent accuracy, ZigBee has limited range (10-20 m, extendable with DSSS), and GSM SMS delivery is unreliable

Proposed system design: use Node MCU as main IoT controller, connect sensors (IR, DHT11, MQ135), use relays to switch appliances, connect OV7670 camera to Arduino UNO, and provide user interface via smartphone/Blink app and email notifications

System claim: combining the same sensor set can address both home security (motion detection and image alert) and home automation (remote control of appliances) while also providing environment monitoring
System advantage claim: using Node MCU with internet connectivity allows control over Wi-Fi or cellular networks (3G/4G) enabling long distance operation and support for handicapped and aged users
Motivation: these identified limitations motivate implementing an IoT based system that uses internet connectivity to overcome short range and reliability issues

Hardware detail: Node MCU (ESP8266-based) is used as the primary IoT board with 16 GPIO pins and Wi-Fi, while Arduino UNO is used to interface the OV7670 camera because Node MCU has only one analog pin
Sensors used and roles: IR sensor for motion detection, DHT11 for temperature and humidity, MQ135 for air purity/gas detection, relay board for switching high current appliances
Camera integration and behavior: OV7670 camera provides 640x480 VGA output, is powered at 3.3V, is connected to Arduino UNO, and is activated when the IR sensor detects motion

Data flow and notifications: when motion is detected the camera captures an image, the image is stored on a PC folder and the system sends the captured image to the predefined user email as an intruder alert
Security workflow claim: upon receiving an emailed image the owner can remotely trigger lights/fans via mobile keypad input or forward the image to authorities if the person is an intruder

Environment monitoring result: DHT11 and MQ135 continuously send readings to the smartphone (updated every second) enabling the user to detect high temperature or gas concentration and remotely turn on fans
Advantage evidence: the prototype can be controlled from long distance via smartphone and shown on the Blink app, demonstrating remote control capability and usability for handicapped and aged people

Conclusion: the implemented IoT system provides a low cost integrated solution for home security, automation, and environment monitoring that leverages internet connectivity to extend range and usability
Limitation and future scope: the system requires internet connectivity to operate, and future implementations could use Raspberry Pi as an alternative platform
